citation.article-title: Stella, a new genus of soil prosthecobacteria, with proposals for Stella humosa sp.nov. and Stella vacuolata sp.nov.

p.s: Description of Stella humosa sp. nov.
Stella humosa (hu.mo'sa. M.L. fem.adj. humosa from soil, earth)
Cells are flat, six-pronged stars 0.7 to 3.0 μm in diameter in dilute media or in media containing low concentrations of nutrients.
The cells occur singly or in pairs.
No clusters or aggregates are formed.
Gram negative with typical three-layered cell envelope.
Ultrastructure typical of gram-negative bacteria.
Nonmotile.
Multiplication occurs by symmetrical cell division.
Aerobic.
The optimum temperature for growth is 28 to 30°C.
Chemoorganotrophic.
A limited number of organic acids of the tricarboxylic acid cycle and amino acids are utilized as energy sources.
Sugars are not utilized.
Yeast extract is required by all strains, but may be replaced by glutamic acid and B vitamins in some strains.
Polysaccharides and proteins are not degraded.
Oligocarbophilic.
The optimum pH range for growth is near neutral for the type strain and slightly alkaline for other strains.
Growth of some strains is stimulated by addition of NaCl (up to a concentration of 1%).
Catalase and oxidase positive.
Susceptible to neomycin (0.5 to 1.0 μg/ml); moderately susceptible to penicillin (8 μg/ml for the type strain) and monomycin (2 to 10 μg/ml for the type strain and strains lob, 10n, 12b, and 12n).
Habitat: widely distributed in soils, freshwater sediments, and sewage and sludge, where rapid decomposition of organic matter is under way.
Participates in final steps of aerobic decomposition.
The G+C content of the DNA is 69.3 to 72.9 mol% (thermal denaturation method).
Plasmids so far not detected.
The type strain is strain AUCM B-1137, which has been deposited in the All Union Collection of Microorganisms, Moscow, USSR, and in the Institute of Microbiology, Academy of Sciences, Moscow, USSR.
